Situation1: It seems your I04iend is confused about the meeting spot, and you need to send a message right now to confirm it.
Situation2: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Story: I sat in the back row of the pharmacy workshop, my phone buzzing insistently in my pocket. The speaker was explaining the latest changes in prescription guidelines, and I knew I needed to pay close attention—my patients depended on me to give them the best advice. But my mind kept drifting to the text from my friend, who sounded confused about where we were supposed to meet later. We’d had a misunderstanding last week, and I promised I’d be clear this time. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing on me: as a pharmacist, I was expected to be fully present and absorb every detail; as a friend, I was supposed to communicate openly and not let things fester. My fingers itched to send a quick message, but I worried about missing something important in the workshop. The tension built inside me, torn between the responsibility to my profession and the promise I’d made to my friend.
